Educational questions invite explanations that can be verified
Demands invite confident fiction
The shift from commanding AI to collaborating wasn’t about being polite

## Appendix

`plaintext
## Prompt:
The data and chart don't really seem to tell a story
What is LDA

## Response:
LDA stands for Latent Dirichlet Allocation, which is a widely used “topic modeling” algorithm
In plain terms, it’s a way to automatically discover the hidden thematic structure in a collection of documents

Here’s the intuition:
Documents are mixtures of topics
Imagine each document as a recipe that mixes a handful of “topics” in different proportions
One document might be 70% about AI ethics and 30% about design process; another could be 50/50 about storytelling and user research
Topics are distributions over words
Each topic, in turn, is defined by a probability distribution over your vocabulary
The “Dirichlet” part refers to a statistical assumption that documents will pick only a few topics (rather than all topics equally), and that topics will emphasize a small subset of words
This makes the model find coherent, focused themes
The algorithm learns from word co-occurrence

modification_path.sentence:
When Collaboration Comes Alive: When Counting Became Analysis

TF-IDF vectorization and cosine similarity finally revealed the semantic patterns that word counts alone had been missing
Word counts, vocabulary shifts, structural evolution

sentence_attributions.final_sentence:
When you feed LDA a corpus (your various draft stages), it iteratively adjusts both:
Which words belong together in a topic (topic → word distributions)
How much of each topic appears in each document (document → topic proportions)

Output you get:
For each document (or stage), a vector of topic proportions (e.g
60% Topic A, 25% Topic B, 15% Topic C)
For each topic, a ranked list of the most representative words
By looking at how those topic proportions change from Draft → Refined → Edited → Final, you can see how the semantic emphasis of your document shifts over time

> A direct comparison between first draft and final version revealed the most startling number: only 61% semantic overlap
